Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Chromosomal Insulators and Insulator Binding Proteins

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to understand how nuclear and chromosomal context establish and maintain patterns of gene expression. The focus is on chromatin domain insulators (also called boundary elements) because the role they play in regulating enhancer promoter communication suggests they might play a broader role in overall chromosome organization. Insulators are DNA elements that define possible regulatory interactions within genomes. They block enhancer-promoter communication, but only when located between the enhancer and promoter. Insulators are thought to allow adjacent genes to be differentially regulated, preventing cross-talk by partitioning them into functionally independent domains. One aim of this project is to study insulator function using genetic tools. Knockout mutations in the single gene encoding these two proteins and in the 32A portion of the gene have been generated by homologous recombination. In addition, flies with a GAL4-inducible transgene encoding a dominant-negative BEAF protein have been generated. The hypothesis that the BEAF proteins play a role in maintaining patterns of gene expression will be tested using gene microarrays with RNA isolated from mutant versus wild-type animals. Knockout flies will also be used in chromatin mapping experiments to test the hypothesis that BEAF plays a role in global chromatin organization. Using BEAF-fluorescent protein fusions in the BEAF knockout background, BEAF localization and dynamics will be studied. The dominant negative transgene was used in a screen to identify genetic interactions. Follow-up experiments will be conducted to gain insight into molecular mechanisms of BEAF function. The second aim is to test the hypothesis that insulators play key roles in linking genome organization to gene expression. A genomic map of BEAF binding sites will be constructed by hybridizing ChIP DNA to genome tiling arrays. This data will be combined with the gene expression microarray analysis of the first aim, to test the hypothesis that BEAF-dependent insulators separate differentially regulated
adjacent genes from each other and play a role in their differential regulation. These experiments are an important test of the role of insulators in relationship to global genomic function, and will provide insight into molecular mechanisms of insulator function.

An integral goal of this study is to train the next generation of scientists. To this end, graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented minority groups, will participate in the research activity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding principles of organization in the nucleus remains an outstanding challenge in cell biology. This is important because processes such as gene regulation during development or in response to environmental signals takes place in the context of nuclear organization and its dynamics. Chromatin domain insulators, also called boundary elements, were proposed as elements that link nuclear organization to gene regulation. In this model, insulators participate in organization by defining the boundaries of domains and participate in gene regulation by blocking inter-domain, but not intra-domain, communication between promoters and regulatory elements. In support of this model, certain DNA sequences block enhancer-promoter communication when located between an enhancer and promoter, and block the spread of condensed chromatin. Inactivation of specific insulators can lead to cancer or developmental abnormalities, demonstrating the importance of insulators in gene regulation. However, little is known about how insulators function at the molecular level.

 

Research funded by this grant took a genomic approach to understanding the role of two closely related insulator proteins in Drosophila melanogaster, the 32 kDa Boundary Element-Associated Factors BEAF-32A and BEAF-32B. The results call the traditional model of insulators into question, at least for BEAF. Nearly 2000 BEAF binding regions were mapped in the genome, and about 85% are within 300 base pairs of a protein-coding gene transcription start site (TSS). If BEAF is insulating these promoter regions from enhancers, then these promoters must be regulated by promoter-proximal and downstream elements. While this is possible, enhancers have often been found upstream of promoters that they regulate.

 

About half of the BEAF binding regions are between two closely spaced, divergently transcribed genes. BEAF might be insulating these two genes from each other, allowing them to be regulated independently of each other. This would be consistent with the traditional model of insulator function. However, three considerations suggest that BEAF might be playing a more direct role in promoter function. First, at least some of these divergently transcribed regions have two BEAF binding sites, one located near each TSS. In collaborative work supported by this grant, this has been termed the “dual-core” model. In the traditional insulator model, BEAF would be expected to bind somewhere between the two TSSs rather than near both. Unfortunately, BEAF binds DNA in an unusual manner so that it is often not possible to determine with certainty exactly where BEAF binds by looking at DNA sequences. Thus it is not clear how many BEAF binding regions between divergent TSSs fit the dual core model. Second, 75% to 95% of the genes with BEAF found near their TSS are expressed at high levels in  diverse tissues. This suggests that many BEAF-associated genes are constitutively expressed, rather than being differentially regulated from their divergently transcribed neighbor. Third, transcription levels of several BEAF-associated genes were measured in fly embryos lacking BEAF or in cultured cells after RNAi-mediated knockdown of BEAF. Results from both methods found that transcription levels of most of these genes decreased when BEAF was absent or reduced.

 

Taken together, research supported by this grant suggests that BEAF plays a role in keeping many housekeeping gene promoters active. Other work from the lab of the PI indicates that BEAF binding sites have insulator activity that depends on BEAF. How the role of BEAF at active promoters relates to its activity in insulator assays and meshes with traditional models of insulator function is an intriguing question.
